qas.question: What type of gender did Old English nouns possess?
What type of gender is present in modern English nouns?
What was a masculine word in Old English?
What was a feminine word in Old English?
What was the grammatical gender of the Old English word for wife?
what did not have a gender in Old English?
What is used to show gender in modern English?
What type of noun refers to a female person in modern English?

context: Old English <b5_0>nouns<b5_0/> had <a0_0>grammatical<a0_0/> gender, a feature absent in modern English, which uses only <a1_0>natural<a1_0/> gender. For example, the words <a3_0>sunne<a3_0/> ("sun"), <a2_0>mōna<a2_0/> ("moon") and wīf ("woman/wife") were respectively feminine, masculine and <a4_0>neuter<a4_0/>; this is reflected, among other things, in the form of the definite article used with these nouns: sēo sunne ("the sun"), se mōna ("the moon"), þæt wīf ("the woman/wife"). <b6_0>Pronoun<b6_0/> usage could reflect either natural or grammatical gender, when those conflicted (as in the case of wīf, <b7_0>a neuter noun<b7_0/> referring to a female person).
